section.title: Locale Session
section.para: The <LocaleSession class provides a variety of functions meant to ease the management a multilingual application. It allows automatic handling of the application's supported languages with the help of a <Zend_Session_Namespace.

With a locale session object, it is possible to know the current locale of an application, the default locale, all the supported locales, if a locale is supported, etc. It also provides behaviours to add locales, switch between locales and reset the locales to the default ones found in the configuration.

In order to supply supported languages to the locale session singleton, simply list all of the supported languages in the configuration using the following syntax:plugins.i18n.supportedLocales[] = es plugins.i18n.supportedLocales[] = fr plugins.i18n.supportedLocales[] = ch

As you may notice in the above example, there is no explicitly defined default language. In that case, Majisti sets the default locale to English (en). It is important to understand the difference between supported languages and the default language. You may wonder "how can English be the default locale when it's not even marked as supported in the configuration file?". Well, the answer is quite simple. You are allowed to put no supported locales at all. Majisti sets the default language in this case to English, as stated before. This means that the default locale and the supported locales are two different concepts. The supported locales do not include the default one. Think of them as "other than the default one" supported locales.

To define the default locale of you application, the configuration setting is quite similar to the one of defining the supported locales. All there is to do is add the following line in the configuration file:plugins.i18n.defaultLocale = fr
